English: Justice is in the hands of various aristocratic and ecclesiastical courts.
Judges are appointed by the central government to regional courts.
There is a unified legal code for the entire polity.
Land is held in feudal terms, with commons and noble estates.
The government has passed private acts enclosing upon commons.
Most land is held in private writs.
The government has established various land banks for the allocation of land.
Many lands are held as cooperatives.
Much land is held in large collectives.
The government makes little effort to restrict bills of exchange.
All banks need a license to issue bills.
There is an established central bank.
There are various bodies dedicated to regulating currency flows.
There is no governmental school system.
The government works with the clergy to provide schooling.
There is a state school system.
The pratice of keeping thralls is permitted.
The pratice of keeping thralls is outlawed.
There is no civil appointment bodies, leading to common nepotism.
Bureaucrats are appointed by the government.
The civil service is meritocratic and outcomes oriented.
The legislative assembly is composed of delegates chosen by hereditary tribal censi.
All hereditary peers of the higher orders have a seat in the legislative assembly.
The legislative assembly is composed of candidates chosen by organised regional election.
The legislature only consists of delegates chosen in elections directed by the central government.
The legislature is composed of civil servants chosen by the ruling party.
There are no laws or instituions regulating or promoting infrastructure development.
Infrastructure is largely funded by regional levies and directed by local authorites.
Most large cities have regional planning authorities.
There is a government public works division to direct and support infrastructure expansion.
There are trinket protections for the worker.
There are low levels of protection for the worker.
There are acceptable levels of protection for the worker.
There are good protections for the worker.
Morality police enforce religious legislation with wide powers.
Clerical courts have the right to prosecute religious offenders and heretics.
Subjects cannot face trial for religious views.
Heterodox views are permitted to form organsations and churches.
Local congregations are free to endorse their own religious views.
Aristocrats have wide proprietary rights against their subjects and the government.
The government endorses a number of privileges held by aristocrats against the lower orders.
The lower orders are prohibited from certain luxuries and conspicous consumption.
Certain castes face a number of legal restritctions.
The government recognises no hereditary disabilities or privileges.
There are no welfare policies in the state.
The government maintains large public granaries to protect against famine.
The government subsidizes large quantities of grain to reduce the price.
Most major cities provide a free grain dole to paupers, invalids, and the unemployed.
The government is commited to providing a mule and yearly grains to its paupers and peasants.
Slaves have some legal protections against abuse.
All slaves are owned by the state.
Slaves are regularly emancipated and those born to slaves are free.
Only our primary culture can vote.
Certain accepted minorities are allowed to participate politically.
All cultures are allowed to participate in the political process.
The border is strictly closed to immigrants.
Quotas carefuly restrict the amount of immigrants.
All immigrants are free to come to our country.
Certain permits allow for legal emigration.
The clergy maintains an extensive private state and judiciary.
The state and the ecclesiastical structure meld into one.
The state is strictly seperate from the clergy, and clerical influence is legislated against.
Those unable to pay their debts descend into hereditary, landbound servitude.
Those unable to pay their debts descend into the service of their creditor.
Those unable to pay their debts are interned in state run labour facilities until their debts are payed.
Those unable to pay their debts may declare bankrupty to seek relief.
The death penalty is a legal and common punishment for certain criminals.
Transportation to colonial servitute is a common punishment for crimes.
Criminals are most often interned in state prisons or dungeons.
Criminals are directed to correctional facilities with an intention to release them after correction.

On the great plains of the continent of Ishahfazh, by the imperial reckoning, the year is 1308. For the past four hundred years, since the traumatic and prolonged shattering of the Gashdzii empire in the times of sorrow, the face of Ishahfazh has been transformed by a series of events and innovations, the implications of which are only now becoming clear. A steady trickle of exploration has mapped the world and brought more and more regions into a global market, while vicious competition, politically and economically, has driven the proliferation of new forms of economic organization and innovations. At the same time, Gashdzii society has been wracked by perennial social upheaval since the collapse of the empire. The traditional lordly and ecclesiastical domination has been steadily challenged in more unstable regions, leading to the gradual development of what has been termed the "anti-magisterial" movement, rejecting centralized ecclesiastical organization. This movement, already tinged with social radicalism, in recent years has taken a critically radical turn. Calling themselves "social liberationists", these radicals seek to overthrow the traditional organization of society at large. Calling for the abolition of proprietary social rights, manorial society, and aristocratic privilege, they seek to establish a society that caters to the common people, and to a traditional agricultural and arcadian lifestyle. As the game begins, the states of Ishahfazh are set poised for a vast confrontation as the very fabric of society changes: the merchants and industrials of the south look to command the very planet by their clever technologies, while the social liberationists across the former empire and its peripheries look to the Siethve liberationist state with all their hopes for a worldly paradise, and in the ancient Poumnian empire and the great Vokonazh domains of the North, the forces of reaction and aristocracy rally their armies...
The trearusy is an extension of the household of the soveriegn.
The royal exchequer is a seperate department in the government.
Much of local governance is left to local estates with quasi-soviergn rights.
The power of local elites are abridged by supervisiory intendants.
Most law remains customary and uncodified, enforced by social pressures and ad hoc relations.
The government now maintains sitting courts for the maintinence of the law.
Most military leaders maintain a private and personal relationship with their soldiers, beyond state conrtol.
There is a professional officer class with a culture of responsibility for the purposes of directing soldiers.
Most organised armies are ad hoc war parties or mercanary bands organised for the sake of a campaign.
The state pays for the maintinence of a regular standing army for defense and offense.
The royal court only assembles on ex tempore occasions.
The government maintains regular royal audiences for the purposes of governance.
Towns and cities have no privlieged legal status.
Towns and cities have been granted special legal protections.
There is no census carried out by the state.
The state has the bureaucratic machinery to carry out an irregular census.
Subjects and residents are able to move as they will.
The state has passed numerous laws to restrict movement of subjects and residents.
Most property laws are only loosely enforced by regional authorities.
All property is guaranteed by royal writs.
Most farming is done on an ad hoc basis in common fields.
The principles of crop rotation and fallowing are widely understood and socially enforced.
Most iron sources are irregular and shallow, such as bog iron harvesting or surface quarries.
Metallurgical pratices are widely understood and iron is very accessable, such that even small villages maintain smithies.
Much record keeping is done by monastic and idiosyncratic chroniclers.
The state maintains a rudimentary records office with professional scribes.
Much education is done by elders and parochial authorities
Standardised cirricula organised by clerical instituions serves to perserve much knowledge and train effective civil servants.
Most local and long distance trade is done by means of clumsy barter.
Trade is facilitated by the near ubiquitous use of bullion and specie.
Trade prospers due to state issued metallic coins.
Most taxes are tributary and head taxes in nature.
Graduated land taxes faciliate access to more regular incomes and tap into the wealth of the landed elites.
The pratice of tax farming, quasi-private offices of collection, ensures the state a regular and flexible supply of income.
Exchange often occurs only on a parish level.
Organised regional fares and broader road systems now faciliate trade on an integrated regional scale.
Trade is done usually in irregular ways and with no set practices.
Regular contractual arrangements, embedded in the legal system, ensure mercantile confidence and stimulate oppertunity.
A wide relgious and philosophical aversion to the multiplication of value has led to restrictions on usury and other instruments of credit.
Bills, credit, loans, and other financial implements are increasingly avaliable and prolific in the financial and mercantile communities.
Most fabrication is done on a pratical or cottage basis, or by regional masters.
Sophisticated guild regulations help manage a quality of output and a quantity of supply, stabalizing and thickening markets.
Liberationists want to pass social reforms, but will pass political reforms under pressure.
Radical liberationists want to pass social reforms and repeal political reforms when they are in power.
Statists want to pass political reforms, but will pass social reforms under pressure.
Absolutists want to pass political reforms when they are in power.
Theocratists will only participate politically if they are in power, and in that case they will tow the party line.
